prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GAMA599582
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal contains the CO(1-0) Band 3 observations of GAMA599582

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We need to have spectral resolution of at least 10 km/s. We have selected the correlator setup providing resolution of ~3 km/s and the data will be rebinned to 10 km/s (or even 20 km/s if there is need to increase S/N further in the outer disc region). The next correlator setting up provides spectral resolution of only ~100 km/s which is far too poor for our science goals over the baseband including the CO(1-0).
The other three basebands have been set to cover as much as possible of the two subbands, in order to try to obtain a 3mm continuum measurement. This would nicely complement our Herschel-SPIRE observations to derive dust masses. For these, we have picked the correlator setup providing 100 km/s resolution to reduce the data rate.

We choose to observe with a synthesized beam of 2". This matches exactly the spatial resolution of the SAMI optical integral field spectroscopy map, which will be the key ancillary data used in the analysis of our ALMA maps. Matching spatial resolution in the two datasets is most desirable. A resolution of 2" can be obtained with configuration C36-2, or in a hybrid configuration with C36-1. The optical diameter of our galaxies are 15-25" (see Fig. 3 in the science justification text). With the proposed setup we will recover flux on scales of up to 25", nicely matching the extent of our galaxies.

Sensitivity calculations were done two ways.
(1) We used the scaling relation for MH2/M* as a function of NUV-r colour from the COLD GASS survey (Saintonge et al. 2011) to estimate the total molecular gas mass for each galaxy. This value of MH2 was converted into an expected total integrated line flux, assuming the redshift and distance of the galaxy, a metallicity-dependent XCO (Genzel et al. 2012). Finally, the peak flux density per beam is obtained by assuming a 50km/s line width in each resolution element and 20 beams covering the galaxy disc (both assumptions are rather conservative). This gives us the peak flux density mentioned above. It gives an idea of the mean flux per beam, but does not take into account that molecular gas typically follows an exponentially declining radial profile.
(2) To take into account these spatial variations in the CO flux, and to make sure that our observations are deep enough to detect CO up to 1.5-2 effective radii, we make a second sensitivity estimate based on the Halpha maps. The SFR in each resolution element is used to estimate the required sensitivity to detect CO emission at S/N>3 using the assumptions listed above. We select as our sensitivity requirement the rms value that will give us S/N>3 through the region where Halpha is well detected in the optical IFS maps. This will allow us to compare the properties of the ionised and molecular gas along and across the disc of the galaxy.
All our calculations are based assuming that we will bin the data to 10 km/s resolution. However, as we will be measuring the data with 3 km/s-wide channels, in regions of higher S/N we will be able to retain the additional spectral resolution to better resolve line profiles. Note that this value of 10 km/s is chosen as this is the typical CO velocity dispersion in local disk galaxies and therefore the CO line will be no narrower than this in each resolution element.

Note that this value of 10 km/s is chosen as this is the typical CO velocity dispersion in local disk galaxies and therefore the CO line will be no narrower than this in each resolution element.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GAMA238221
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal contains the CO(1-0) Band 3 observations of GAMA238221

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We need to have spectral resolution of at least 10 km/s. We have selected the correlator setup providing resolution of ~3 km/s and the data will be rebinned to 10 km/s (or even 20 km/s if there is need to increase S/N further in the outer disc region). The next correlator setting up provides spectral resolution of only ~100 km/s which is far too poor for our science goals over the baseband including the CO(1-0).
The other three basebands have been set to cover as much as possible of the two subbands, in order to try to obtain a 3mm continuum measurement. This would nicely complement our Herschel-SPIRE observations to derive dust masses. For these, we have picked the correlator setup providing 100 km/s resolution to reduce the data rate.

We choose to observe with a synthesized beam of 2". This matches exactly the spatial resolution of the SAMI optical integral field spectroscopy map, which will be the key ancillary data used in the analysis of our ALMA maps. Matching spatial resolution in the two datasets is most desirable. A resolution of 2" can be obtained with configuration C36-2, or in a hybrid configuration with C36-1. The optical diameter of our galaxies are 15-25" (see Fig. 3 in the science justification text). With the proposed setup we will recover flux on scales of up to 25", nicely matching the extent of our galaxies.

Sensitivity calculations were done two ways.
(1) We used the scaling relation for MH2/M* as a function of NUV-r colour from the COLD GASS survey (Saintonge et al. 2011) to estimate the total molecular gas mass for each galaxy. This value of MH2 was converted into an expected total integrated line flux, assuming the redshift and distance of the galaxy, a metallicity-dependent XCO (Genzel et al. 2012). Finally, the peak flux density per beam is obtained by assuming a 50km/s line width in each resolution element and 20 beams covering the galaxy disc (both assumptions are rather conservative). This gives us the peak flux density mentioned above. It gives an idea of the mean flux per beam, but does not take into account that molecular gas typically follows an exponentially declining radial profile.
(2) To take into account these spatial variations in the CO flux, and to make sure that our observations are deep enough to detect CO up to 1.5-2 effective radii, we make a second sensitivity estimate based on the Halpha maps. The SFR in each resolution element is used to estimate the required sensitivity to detect CO emission at S/N>3 using the assumptions listed above. We select as our sensitivity requirement the rms value that will give us S/N>3 through the region where Halpha is well detected in the optical IFS maps. This will allow us to compare the properties of the ionised and molecular gas along and across the disc of the galaxy.
All our calculations are based assuming that we will bin the data to 10 km/s resolution. However, as we will be measuring the data with 3 km/s-wide channels, in regions of higher S/N we will be able to retain the additional spectral resolution to better resolve line profiles. Note that this value of 10 km/s is chosen as this is the typical CO velocity dispersion in local disk galaxies and therefore the CO line will be no narrower than this in each resolution element.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Large-scale outflows of gas are a central element of all galaxy evolution models, yet their properties are not well constrained observationally. We propose to observe a sample of 16 local galaxies (0.02<z<0.06) discovered by the SAMI survey to have a range of wind strengths, including galaxies with strong galactic-scale outflows all the way to control galaxies of similar masses and SFRs, but with no evidence of outflows. We will obtain CO(1-0) maps matching the spatial resolution of the optical IFS data with these objectives: 1) We will quantify the impact of the outflows on the molecular gas reservoirs of the galaxies, and on local star formation rate surface density and gas depletion timescale. 2) We will study the properties of the outflows themselves. Comparing velocity dispersions and mass outflow rates of the ionised and molecular gas, we will study the transfer of energy from stellar winds to the ISM, and the phase of the outflowing material. We will derive scaling relations between mass outflow rates and M*, v_rot, and Sigma_SFR, to directly confront theoretical predictions and inform us on the mechanisms driving galactic-scale outflows in normal star-forming galaxies.
